Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Glacier-Ocean Coupling in a Large East Greenland Fjord
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a study of glacier-fjord interactions in east Greenland. The 'Intellectual Merit' of the proposed study lies in the current understanding that the contribution of the Greenland Ice Sheet to sea level rise more than doubled in the last seven years, mostly because of a widespread and nearly simultaneous acceleration of many glaciers that terminate at tidewater in deep fjords. Understanding the causes of changes in glacier dynamics, and predicting their future trajectories is a topic of enormous scientific and societal importance. The Greenland fjords provide an intimate connection between the ice sheet and the ocean and, in turn, raise the possibility that the observed warming of the ocean around southeast and western Greenland was the trigger for recent changes in outlet glacier dynamics.

A pilot study conducted by the PIs in east Greenland, and a separate study in west Greenland, found warm ocean waters in the proximity of Helheim Glacier and Jakobshavn Isbr√¶, respectively, supporting the hypothesis that their acceleration was triggered by ocean warming. While intriguing, the presence of warm waters in Greenland's fjords alone is not enough to conclude that the ocean is modulating glacier dynamics. A test of this hypothesis requires a more detailed understanding of glacier/fjord interactions than is possible with the limited amount of data currently available. This study will fill this gap by investigating glacier-ocean interactions in a typical glacier-fjord system in East Greenland (Sermilik Fjord and Helheim Glacier) through an intensive two-year field program. Through summer surveys and year-round moored instruments, the circulation and properties of the fjord on tidal to yearly time-scales will be mapped, and the liquid fresh water flux out of the fjord will be quantified. A collaboration with Greenlandic marine biologists will allow important ocean data in the region outside the fjord to be obtained using tagged seals. GPS methods and remote sensing will allow changes in the flow behavior of Helheim Glacier to be examined in the context of changing fjord circulation. Satellite remote sensing and field tracking of large icebergs will provide estimates of the solid export of fresh water and its variability.

The proposed study has numerous 'Broader Impacts'. The are likely to be a significant component of next-generation ice sheet models seeking to predict the evolution of the Greenland Ice Sheet and future rates of sea level rise. The project brings together an inter-disciplinary group of investigators, involves two junior scientists embarking on their careers, and initiates an international collaboration with Greenlandic scientists. A graduate student will be trained in glaciology and physical oceanography, contributing to society's need for experts in the area of ice sheet-ocean interactions. The fieldwork utilizes local vessels and relies strongly on the knowledge of generations of local hunters who have navigated Sermilik Fjord, thus fostering a two-way exchange between the local community and foreign scientists. A non-technical report summarizing the findings of ocean-glacier measurements will distributed in the local community, which is vulnerable to rapid environmental changes affecting its primary natural resource.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Widespread retreat of glaciers in Greenland over the last two decades has been attributed to changes at the glacier/ocean intersection, at the head of narrow, long fjords that connect the ice sheet with the large-scale ocean. Cumulatively these glacier changes have contributed to a sizable portion of the observed sea level rise. Yet the mechanisms that resulted in glacier change are unclear and the changes were not predicted by ice sheet or glacier models.

In this project we have investigated what governs the changes in forcing at the glacier/ocean boundary and whether these changes can be linked to changes in behavior of the glacier. The work has focused on Helheim Glacier - a large glacier in southeast Greenland that has undergone rapid change over the last two decades. Oceanographic and glaciological data has been collected from 2010 to 2013 from the fjord and nearby shelf region, and from the glacier terminus. Glacier measurements have included time-lapse cameras and GPS measurements as well as the analysis of remote sensing data. Ocean measurements have been collected via moorings deployed from one summer to the next, and via-ship based and helicopter based surveys.

Analysis of the ocean data has shown that the fjord contains cold fresh Arctic waters near the surface and warm, salty Atlantic waters at depth and that these are present year round. Moored measurements have provided the first long-term record of the variability in fjord properties (including temperature and velocity) in the fjord. They have revealed that this is a highly dynamic system with fast and rapidly reversing currents forced by storms transiting along the southeast coast of Greenland. This means that the warm, Atlantic waters which drive melting at the edge of the glacier are continuously replenished and can contribute to more melting. Furthermore, we have shown that in summer the fjord contains large amounts of fresh water from surface melt of the glacier. These waters are injected at the base of the glacier, hundreds of meters below the surface, and can greatly enhance the summer melt. The bottom line is that melting of the glacier face is controlled both by the fjord properties and by the discharge of surface melt in summer.

A comparison of the ocean data with the glacier data indicates that the seasonal speedup of the glacier starts at the time when the discharge of surface melt starts. Variations from one year to the next indicate that the glacier retreats the most in years when both the fjord waters are warmer and the discharge of surface melt is larger. Both mechanisms are supportive of changes being forced at the glacier/ocean terminus - supporting the linked presumed above.

In summary, this project has advanced our understanding of the coupled glacier/ocean system by collecting some unprecedented data at the edge of Helheim Glacier. Major findings include the role of storms in flushing these fjords and the impact of fjord stratification and surface melt on melt at the glacier face. The greater understanding of these mechanisms achieved by this project will lead to their improved representation in ocean, ice sheet and Earth System Models - thus increasing our ability to predict future changes.
